subject: RE: [junit] Re: JUnit considered problematic
msgSnippet: ... With all due respect, perhaps you should concentrate more on learning than on convincing others. ... And then you need to somehow run the system through
messageBody:
> I wish I would be a expert to convince you of a better approach than
> JUnit provides (and TDD).

With all due respect, perhaps you should concentrate more on learning
than on convincing others.

> Testing of the code (methods) can be done with precondition,
> invartiants and postconditions (the contracts). Thats how I
> understand Design by Contract. You write your method definition and
> then you write the contract for it. Then you implement your method.

And then you need to somehow run the system through different scenarios,
so it seems to me.

> Now the great thing: When you compile your code the implementation
> can be checked whether it obeys the contract. If not, a compile error
> is thrown. That it!

Have you tried this? AFAIK, contracts are checked at runtime, not
compile time.

Don't know about JML, though I wonder how they would do it at compile
time...

> No JUnit test needed! Not TDD needed! Besides
> this, a contract serves as a documentation.

Unit tests do that, too. They even serve as examples on how the code is
expected to be used - DBC doesn't do that.

> And it can use invariants
> which JUnit will always lack of.

OTOH, DBC can't test the interaction of several objects as intensive as
Junit can.

> Now come on and don't tell me: "We always used JUnit, most people do,
> why do you little inexperienced programer think you have a better
> idea than people like Gamma or Fowler?"

I'd rather suggest to *try* both your idea and Junit (and possibly even
TDD) for a reasonable time and *then* report about your findings.

> I am not satisfied with the JUnit and TDD "paradigma".

That's OK.

> They are
> originated because of a *poverty* in Java programing language. If
> Java would support proper Design by Contract and a compiler for that
> than no one would bother with JUnit and TDD.

That somehow contradicts the existence of EiffelUnit, doesn't it? See
http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?DesignByContractVsProgrammerTests

BTW, there are implementations of DBC for Java - and TDDers using it are
reporting that DBC and Junit are rather complementing.

Regards, Ilja
